content.description: Includes cocaine, amphetamine-type substances (e.g., methamphetamine), and other psychostimulants. Disorders involve problematic patterns of use, acute intoxication with heightened arousal, and withdrawal characterized by dysphoria and fatigue.

mechanisms: Increase synaptic dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin via transporter blockade or reverse transport.
Chronic exposure leads to neuroadaptive changes in reward circuitry and stress systems.
Neurotoxicity may involve oxidative stress, excitotoxicity, and altered neuroplasticity.

diagnostic_criteria.use_disorder: Problematic pattern of stimulant use leading to impairment/distress with ≥2 DSM-5 criteria in a 12-month period.
diagnostic_criteria.intoxication: Recent stimulant use with problematic behavioral/psychological changes (e.g., euphoria, hypervigilance, anxiety) plus ≥2 of: tachycardia/bradycardia, pupillary dilation, BP changes, perspiration/chills, nausea/vomiting, weight loss, psychomotor agitation/retardation, chest pain, arrhythmia, confusion, seizures.
diagnostic_criteria.withdrawal: Cessation/reduction in heavy/prolonged use with dysphoric mood and ≥2 of: fatigue, vivid unpleasant dreams, insomnia/hypersomnia, increased appetite, psychomotor changes.

content.prevalence: Cocaine use disorder affects ~1% of U.S. adults; amphetamine misuse is rising, including prescription stimulants.
content.age_of_onset: Often begins in late adolescence or early adulthood, sometimes with prescribed stimulants.
content.prognosis: Variable; high relapse rates without structured treatment, but better with comprehensive behavioral interventions.

history: Substance type, route, amount, and frequency.

biological: Family history of stimulant or other substance use disorders

impact_on_life.social: Conflict, isolation, or risky sexual behavior.
impact_on_life.medical: Cardiac events, seizures, weight loss, poor nutrition.

medications: No FDA-approved medications; off-label: bupropion, modafinil, topiramate may be tried in some cases.
intoxication_management: Benzodiazepines for severe agitation or seizures.

treatment_goals: Address co-occurring psychiatric and medical issues.
Develop healthy coping and relapse prevention skills.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing hyperactivity or insomnia to anxiety alone.
overdiagnosis_factors: Mislabeling normal alertness from caffeine as stimulant intoxication.
self_help_strategies: Exercise to support mood and energy.

adolescents: Misuse of ADHD medications for performance.
older_adults: Rare, but possible in chronic prescribed stimulant overuse.

real_life_examples: A college student abusing Adderall during finals and experiencing paranoia.
A construction worker using methamphetamine to work longer shifts, leading to weight loss and dental decay.
A person with cocaine binges every weekend followed by severe Monday fatigue.
